narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learn a lot about sets, in a really rigorous way. First you learn the axioms, then you move onto operations, induction, relations and functions. Toward the end you move onto cardinality, where you learn about countable and uncountable sets, and then transfinite numbers. You learn to think from scratch.
Learnt a great deal about proofs and formal math.
I learned how to write feet formal proofs following axiomatic set theory.
The course effectively laid out the basis of set theory and foundational proof techniques.
I learned a lot about the background behind math. Looking at topics Ive heard of from a different viewpoint.
Proof-based math
I gained insight into the fundamentals of set theory, as well as the basic structure behind everyday arithmetic.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More office hours and engagement with the professor. It was a class that really felt like you were just talking to a computer. Engagement could have been higher, specially since material was harder than usual.

Strengths: Well Structured
Weakness: Material was a bit hard to follow at times

I though in general the structure of the course of was very good, and the psets and exams were very fair. Though, I think presenting the material at a slightly slower pace could make the class more interesting.
The teaching was very clear and effective, although the pace was somewhat slow.
I really wish there were peer tutors but I felt the professor really tried to make the material understandable.
This course was a great way to learn simultaneously with reading the very the logical progression of material within the textbook
Yofeng does a great job of clearly explaining every and any concept. The course would have been more practical  if we were allowed to work with each other on problem sets, as we are in most classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As said before, more ways to engage with the professor would have been great. OH were at a sort of inconvenient time.
In general, this course was well adapted for COVID-19.
I think the professor was able to teach very well online and the course did not feel overwhelming during this time.
Posting the lectures really helped for review.
Fairly standard recorded lecture / live attendance optional course

The use of a digital whiteboard was useful in its flexibility whenever someone asked a question. Had the teacher been using a slideshow, it would have been difficult to explain concepts they had not prepared for. The writing was hard to read at times however.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, specially to another math or philosophy student. Its a very cool way to see math built from scratch basically.
Yes I would if you want a formal introduction to the most basic concepts in math.
Sure! Lectures can get a little boring at times, but the psets can be enjoyable and the course material is interesting in general.
Yes- I think it provided exactly what I wanted in a set theory course.
Only if they really like math.

I took Math 270 with Prof. Zuckerman last semester before dropping out and taking it again with Prof. Liu this semester. They have two very different teaching methods, Prof. Zuckerman told long-winded but engaging stories about the development of the field of Set Theory while Prof. Liu followed the book fairly consistently. I would highly recommend getting / printing the textbook to read along and take notes in during class. Although we did not cover all of the syllabus, we managed to cover everything from the 6 basic axioms to properties of ordinal numbers (Chapter 6). You can learn all of the necessary vocabulary to understand the Axiom of Choice, which I found rewarding. Take it if you have to, but even as an elective math course there is something interesting and non-trivial to be found within the world of sets. Exams were not easy but we were given ample time and open-notes. Finally, I would urge you to read up on the research of both Prof. Zuckerman and Prof. Liu, as they have done some pretty amazing work in their respective fields with symbolic languages.
Yes, this is a staple course for any mathematics or philosophy major, but on top of that, this course would serve well as an introduction to higher maths.
